Having due regard to the need to advance equality of opportunity involves the need to:

  • remove or minimise disadvantages suffered by persons who share a relevant protected characteristic;
  • take steps to meet the needs of persons who share a relevant protected characteristic;
  • encourage persons who share a relevant protected characteristic to participate in public life or in any other activity in which participation by such persons is disproportionately low.

    • The steps involved in meeting the needs of disabled persons include, in particular, adjustments to take account of specific disabilities. Put simply, ?due regard? means consciously thinking about equality impacts as part of the process of decision making.

    If services do not think (and act) consciously in this way, and evidence their thinking, they are at risk of being non-compliant with the Equality Act, and could face a judicial challenge.

    Having due regard to the need to foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not share it involves having due regard, in particular, to the need to:

    • tackle prejudice;
    • promote understanding.

    It is acceptable for a #{function_policy_substitution} to treat persons with protected characteristics more favourably than thos not sharing protected charcteristics.

column3:
This Initial Assessment should be completed at the earliest opportunity and will determine whether or not it is necessary to carry out a Full Equality Assessment.

The Initial Assessment assesses whether the policy, strategy, function or service may have an impact either positively or negatively on any customer group, staff, part of a community or identity, and should demonstrate:
  • That the policy, strategy, function or service is robust.
  • That there is no potential for discrimination or adverse impact.
  • All opportunities to promote equality have been taken


The use of supporting data and intelligence is vital to the decision taken at this stage. If you do not have sufficient evidence to make an informed decision you need to progress to a Full Equality Assessment. This will help you to establish if there is an impact and help identify how or where to make adjustments.

If you are aware that there may be an impact, but you are not ready at this stage to go on to a more detailed analysis, you must explain this. (For example an EA to support a cabinet report to agree principles or funding to start an initiative)

TIPS:
  • Use facts, figures, and supporting data
  • Evidence your decision making
  • Describe any adjustments which have been made
  • The larger the demographic impacted, the more likely you need to undertake a full assessment


If adjustments cannot be made due to technical or business reasons you must explain the business case behind your decisions.

column2: This must capture your final analysis and understanding of assessment being undertaken to arrive at your decision.
column3:
In completing this section you will have identified that your assessment:
  • Demonstrates ??due regard? to the 3 aims of the General Duty
  • Consultation and Engagement has been undertaken and has informed decision making;
  • Consideration has been given to take account of disabled persons?? disabilities, even where that involves treating disabled persons more favourably than other persons;
  • Relevant information (key findings of the assessment ) have been documented;
  • Where an adverse impact has been identified, consideration has been given on how to mitigate the impact
  • Considerations have been given to alternate options;
  • Provides adequate records detailing how decisions have been made at relevant stages, through out the Assessment;
  • Actions completed;
  • Provides information on how you intend to utilise the findings as part of your decision-making;
  • Provides details on how your policy will meet the city councils responsibility in relation to equality;
  • Demonstrates how you will engage service users, employees in implementation, monitoring and review;
  • Demonstrates what changes/modifications will now be made to the policy in the light of this Assessment;
  • Cabinet members have been provided with the relevant information on this proposal, prior to decision making


Finally, if any further work needs to be done on this Assessment, you will need to state this.

TIPS:
  • If there is a disproportional impact that cannot be addressed through mitigation or adjustment you MUST explain the business case and reasoning behind this decision and the options that have been explored to try to resolve any issues. If these options have been rejected, you must explain why.

    Remember that this is a public document and is likely to be published.

Having due regard to the need to advance equality of opportunity between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not share it involves the need to:

  • remove or minimise disadvantages suffered by persons who share a relevant protected characteristic that are connected to that characteristic;
  • take steps to meet the needs of persons who share a relevant protected characteristic that are different from the needs of persons who do not share it;
  • encourage persons who share a relevant protected characteristic to participate in public life or in any other activity in which participation by such persons is disproportionately low.

    • The steps involved in meeting the needs of disabled persons that are different from the needs of persons who are not disabled include, in particular, steps to take account of disabled persons?? disabilities.Having due regard to the need to foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not share it involves having due regard, in particular, to the need to:

    • tackle prejudice;
    • promote understanding.

    It is acceptable that this #{function_policy_substitution} treats some persons more favourably than others.
